reviewText:
The Good:

It will satisfy your RPG thirst... for a while (about 20-30 hours until you hit a grind wall or a realization of a huge game flaw which will be explained later in this review).  The story is decent.  It isn't your cliche cookie cutter story out of a rpg recycling bin, and is good enough to come back for more.

There are lots of quests to do, besides the main story line.  In fact, later on, most of the leveling will occur from doing sidequests rather than the main questline.  At any time of the day, there will be a global event for you to participate in and earn gold or gear.

There is a guild system and a PVP system.  There are 2 types of PVP, which I find pretty ingenious.  The first is your regular PVP combat... the more powerful character wins.  The second is where the game equalizes the playing field for both characters.  In other words, a lvl 50 character vs a lvl 10 haracter will have the same exact stats.  This helps newbies become acclimated to the combat system.

THe PVP system is also implemented in a variety of ways.  There are 2v2, 3v3, 1v1 equalized PVP duels.  There are guild wars.  There is a regular 1v1 pvp based on the strength of your character with the AI controlling the opponet.

The Bad:

It's... yes, you guessed it, a godamn pay to win. I have added a few of the top players (ranked in PVP and level) how they attained their current statuses.  One told me she paid $1000 (no I counted the zeroes correcly) and the top 2 paid over $2k. The items that are purchasable only with electrum (the in game currency only obtainable through cash) are ultra end game gear that have no level requirement.  It takes about a little over $100 USD to gather most of it.  (If you want all of the gear, itll be an upwards of 200, excluding armor upgrades which can become very costly.)

What's worse is that this gear is unobtainable anywhere else.  You MUST pay.  While other games may offer xp boosts, temporary gold gain boosts, or a sweet aesthetic item (like leagues of legends), this game falls within the very definition of pay to win: exclusive ultra gear for those who drop money. (Even Leagues lets you eventually buy champions if you grind hard enough. This game doesn't.)

Sadly, it rewards this type of behavior.  Those who pay money, even get to claim more rewards for charging their credit cards.

Consequently, this Pay to Win encouragement totally destroys the guild PVP system out of the water due to the higher tier companies having members who have paid their way to glory.

Aside from the major pay to win flaw, there are other faults with the game.  Item customization is very lackluster.  While there are color rankings for rarity, there is no INHERENT customization of stats.  E.G. Diablo 2 had great item customization in terms of different rare items providing alternate stats to skills and even helped characters gain abilities.  For CoS, the rarer the weapon, the stronger the stat.  Each item adds one stat. (Yes, just one stat... different pieces of gear add different stats)  Item customization is minimal.

SO is the skill system. Over the course of your gameplay your character will receive 5 more skills on top of 3 default ones.  You unlock a skill every 5 or 10 levels.  When you do unlock a new skill: you are given a choice of 3 different skills that do different higs.  You pick one and level it up as you progress.  This means, the game has 15 different skills for each character.... as I said, builds are not very diverse.  This is not like D2 where there are vastly different builds... a different build varies by 2 skills. THATS IT.

Gameplay is unresponsive and at times, is severely handicappd by lag.  Lag is a reocurring problem as there are only 2 servers.. both located in the US.

As you begin playing, the pay to win problems will be masked by the fact that there are just so many evets abvailable for you to do.  However, as you begin to gain a decent grasp of what the game offers, you slowly realize the huge, lingering grind wall in front of you.  The novelty wears off, and the tedium of grinding begins.  Main quests are the same: dungeon clearing with a boss at the end.   This is when you start searching for alternate methods of lveling faster, as it begins increasingly difficult to reach the next level.

This is where you fall trapped to the pay to win scheme. You begin to think bout spending real cash on offers such asbrand new ultra gear!" "Tired of being ♥♥♥♥♥? SPend 200 dolars and become awesome!"

Bottom Line: The game is pure pay to win.  Unbearably and horribly pay to win. Stay away.  It encourages the behaviour with rewards for those who spend money.  Not worth your time. Spend your time elsewhere looking for another RPG.  Not here."

I'm going to be honest...I kind of liked this game, at the start. Steampunk and fantasy, what could go wrong? And at the start, it was quite fun, seemed like good story...until you get to Arkadia.

It doesn't take long for the game to get repetetive. In fact, to level up all you need to do is log into the game and claim daily prizes, that's about it. Fighting is routine, just mash hordes of monsters. As a player of MMOs such as Dungeons & Dragons Online and The Lord of the Rings Online, I had high hopes for City of Steam.

Alas, while it was cool in the beginning...it gets boring once you get to the main city in the game. There's not much storyline after the intro, and you can't do much in the way of exploring. The races are balanced, the concept of the game is very promising...but if you're intending on playing it past the intro, I can't suggest it. All it's good for in the end is going into a dungeon and killing hordes of bugs and mechanical annoyances, which aren't that hard to beat. Even the bosses are easy to take down. As a player of MMOs, I was hoping for more actual fighting and...well, being able to explore the world.

As much as I wish I could, I can't recommend this game. Does the story show promise? Yes. Could the game have been more than it is? Yes. The sad part is the developers didn't take that route, and City of Steam: Arkadia seems like it's vastly unfinished in terms of story and exploration.

PvP is really crap considering the game is Pay 2 Win

While the quest felt rewarding at times,you pretty much done the same thing over and over again but with horrible combat system.

FINAL VERDICT : 3.8/10

Stay far away from this game. It is heavily pay 2 win and the loading times between small area is just unbearable.

This game is basically MMORPG for lazy cause of the auto-battle mode and inconherent quest trackers.

Those who have patient to reach to level 30+. Kudos to you.

reviewText:
The weirdest game I was not playing. Even though I was playing it.
Like spectating a really bored gamer playing a boring game.

To understand what I mean, you need to know that the game features two vital functions:
Auto-run to get to quest locations, and auto-combat which will spam all your skills it can and glug any potions you need for either Health or Mana. (called 'Steam' in this game)

And that's all you need to know. If you're not fighting or moving, click the quest marker and your character will go there. Upon which they'll then end up fighting if that is required, which is automatised as well. And in general, the game's enemies are simple enough that, all you would have to do anyway is spam your skills. That's all there is to it.

The 'selling point' for this game is that it's a mere 50mb. A nice premise, but there are flashgames out there that take less than 1mb and are tremendously more fun than this. Again, there is no reason to not play this game on auto-mode because in 95% of the time, it is the most efficient way. Not to mention that potions are stupidly cheap to buy in mass ammount, and auto-combat includes auto-looting.

In fact, whenever you pick up gear that is a straight upgrade to what's equipped, it will prompt you to equip it. Have skillpoints or stat points to spend? The game will remind you of this and offer a convenient 'automatic' button that'll spend these in the amount best suited to your class.

Everything in this game is designed to remove any thought process from you. You choose a class, choose a race with a handful of variations, have a VERY basic array of options to change your hair (the face is stuck with the one of the 'race presets' you picked) aaaaand... that's it. Press quest marker to continue.

There are games out there that make tremendous usage with little space. They draw you in, even if their style happens to be 8-bit. And then there's games that use very little space, and have absolutely nothing to show for that feat. City of Steam just doesn't bring anything worthwhile to the table.

Don't get me wrong, it doesn't do anything particularly horribly bad. If anything, what the game does is simply somewhat sub-par, beneath the commonly accepted standard across the board. This game just enables you to turn it into a lazy man's game, a detriment to an already unimpressive title.

Honestly, this shouldn't be on PC. This should just be on iOS and Android and it would flourish like crazy. games that size are not uncommon and it wouldn't be impossible to translate the controls.
Maybe it already is on mobile devices, but I'm having a mighty hard time finding it.

I would really just say... don't bother with it unless you've got absolutely nothing else to do and you want to spend that free time on something that won't enrage you.
But neither will it really engage you.

I came back to this game after a while, mainly for nostalgic reasons. My experience is rather mixed.

The environment is wonderful, the story interesting and the in-game universe has a great potential. There's many races to choose from and the way the world works is amazing. Unfortunately, this potential is unfulfilled because so far there's very little difference between the stories of various races and the game itself makes the player focus on other things (mostly PvP). The RPG element is kinda taken away because your dialogue choices don't really matter.

However, every steampunk fan should try this game. It's a great inspiration for costumes and/or steampunk props, some armor sets are kinda cool and there's not only steam guns but steam swords too! (not sure how that works but whatever) Plus the soundtrack is A+ and gives the game a nice touch.

Possibly the worst thing (or two things) is that it's pay-to-win and if something goes wrong the support won't help you because they're gone. No updates for months, no bug fixes, dead forums. Many players experience problems with loading or other things and there's no response from the devs or anyone. Some people are complaining about the auto-combat feature but it's completely optional. Turn it off.

My recommendation would go like this:
Try it. Play the game for a while and see how you like it.
But don't take it too seriously and don't use your real money on it.

TL;DR

+ environment and lore
+ soundtrack
+ skills animations
+ detailed weapons/armor
+ wheelie on a steambike

+/- auto-combat feature (optional)
+/- focused on PvP at higher levels

- non-existent support
- pay-to-win
- bugs, bugs, bugs

reviewText:
First, the bad news. The first time you do a (level 10?) dungeon (PER character), expect the game to lock the dungeon reward screen on you to the point you have exit out of the game. Near as I can tell, this only happence once per character. For good or bad, you get 5 characters per account. Any server you log into will show any characters you have already made.

The game is sometimes hard to log into. They seem to be working hard on content and bugs. I got fairly quick responses to the emails I sent to them, and have edited and kept this review updated accordingly.

Next, the good news. Its actually worth dealing with bugs till they fix it.  My husband and I discovered this game on the same day, and as we played, it seemed every 10 minutes or so we were finding something new that we loved about the game. I haven't seen him this hooked in a loong time.  I've paid it the highest compliment I know how for a game... I created a solo... I almost never solo.  Yeah, its that much fun. If you like steampunk at all, you want to give it a shot.

Yes, the character creation is exceedingly limited, and the classes *seem* limited. Trust me, by level 6 or so you dont care. The classes have variations within them. And the looks of the character constantly develop in game, given a combination of luck and your taste.

They are generous with rewards for those who log in every day for up to seven days in a row, and have a constantly changing event giving out new rewards simply for being logged in and playing on any given day. Almost everything you do has a completion reward, collection reward, something extra built into it. It may sound overwhelming, but give yourself a day and you will find that they did an excellent job of helping you track it. While it may seem too easy at first, you really come to  appreciate their ingenious ways of helping you to track as you level up and find more to keep track of.

Now something that some will see as horrible and others as excellent... I happen to love it. This game reaches new heights in pitting brain vs brawn. If all you do is push to level up to max in one weekend, you could find yourself with a level 50 character with little better than level 10 abilities. Every time I play I find new ways they give to make your character unique. There are miriad ways to buy, build, plan, level everything about your character, and every level counts. Each time you finish your quest and level up, take the time to look around, did you do your dailies and level up your abilities? Do you spend more on your merc(battle pet, in essense) or more on your armor, or more on your abilities? Do you buy more bag space or a better buff pet? All choices are good, and all take time to build.  If you love to do a slow, thorough build of your character, like I do, you will find this game addictive. If you are all about the max level as fast as possible, you may find yourself a little frustrated with having to slow down and plan your character. Either player type given time can find themselves addicted to this game.

Hope this review helps. Keep up the good work!

reviewText:
Gritty graphics and linear gameplay that basically plays itself.

CoS is a very casual MMO that could be considered a point and click. The Combat system is so easy you can play without using your skills for the first 10 levels.

I don't mind linear gameplay, its helpful and simple sometimes but when the game basically holds your hand though the entire thing, its just plain boring. It's certainly noob friendly, which is always a bonus.

Skill system is also very simple and slow, since you only get new abilities every several levels, there isn't any variety. From research through reviews and videos, it also seems like the gear is also bland and generic, making end game pointless.

Many dailies that allow you to gain loot,experience and mastery/expertise points to level up your core stats and upgrade your abilities.

PvP system is slow and primitive, lagging out like crazy and giving players unfair advantages.
This is strickly a PvE game.

Gambling system, where you can use special orbs to try and get in game currency and items. Auction house and many vendors to buy items with special currency aquired during heroic mode dungeons, pvp, or special events.

Also, pay to win, which is always fun. But hey, its a free game that can be classifed as a MMORPG Point and Click. Free, noob friendly, linear as ♥♥♥♥ and easy as hell.

If your looking for a free, casual and easy RPG, give it a try. (its more RPG than MMO in my opinion)

Personal Rating: 3/5

Heck yeah! Steampunk! Heck no, terrible game.

The world itself isn't very compelling. Sure it felt like a Steampunk environment, but the overall game environment was extremely bland. The questing system was a constant extermination and delivery quest type, both of which can get boring really quickly.

The game itself was incredibly.. uninteresting. The combat wasn't engaging, the quest-line wasn't engaging, not even the environment was engaging. This game provided 0 immersion for me, it was a huge waste of time.

If I have anything good to say about this game, I'd say that it'd be the concept. The concept of a Steampunk MMORPG. Although there may be a few Steampunk mmo's, I haven't seen them, but I would like to see a good quality one.

I'll give this a 2/10. It has agreeable asethetics and graphics, but the overall game is just terrible.

an experience bar, and a shillings bar. In order for you to complete nearly any real objective (excluding standard 'go talk to this fellow' quests) you are directed to an open instance in which you pretty much just murder everything for a minute or two, click a shiny clearly visible objective, and leave. Sometimes you have to kill a boss as well, but with the volume of people inside the instance with you, you normally don't have to actually kill it, in fact you dont even have to hit the thing, you can walk in and someone can get the killing blow on the boss creature and you instantly get credit for the kill as well. The combat its self doesnt aid in making the grinding any more enjoyable. I myself played a warder, the warrior class of City of Steam. While the class had some interesting mechanics, one of which being switching between equipped weapon sets to boost different stats, the combat is generally uninteresting and bland. You have a resource, you have health, you have some buttons. You click, character whacks, you press a button should you feel the need to (I rarely did) and then numbers and death proceed to spread everywhere.

The game's aesthetic design however is somewhat nice, I 'll give it that, but only to a certain degree. The game has some decent style despite having relatively dated graphics, however this style is quickly ruined by the vast amount of clutter and dull color palette used within the game. Being steampunk focused, I can't expect too many color splashes, but the way that the game is presented with its browns and metallic grays just makes the game look confusing and crowded. On the note of aesthetics I will say the character customization is okay, all of the races look relatively interesting... all but one... the only one I wanted to play. That being the orcs. Now every race in this game has SOMETHING about them that makes them look a little stupid, whether it be a somewhat silly facial expression locked on their face, a strange array of hairstyles, huge ears etc, but the orcs just downright look terrible, and I love orcs, so this made me sad. Their hair looked glued onto their heads, their moustaches looked like paper cutouts hanging under their noses, and the beards looked no better. Well at least I looked pretty neat on the free motorcycle dressed in my overly badass level 5 armor.

Yes I said motorcycle. Everyone gets one for free very early in game, as far as I know this is the only mount in the game. The motorcylce can be upgraded with vehicle parts to go faster and look cooler (though I thought the last several upgrades available looked less like badass steampunk motorcycles and more like something I would unlock in Mario Kart) but the upgrades are another way of getting your money, you need more and more parts to upgrade it, and one of the ways you can get them is connected to the payment system.

All in all the game is by no means the worst game I've ever played, and I admit I didnt play very much, but the first impression is always the strongest in an MMO, and sometimes you can just tell when an MMO will play the same throughout, this was a strong feeling with this game in particular.

I wouldnt recommend it to anyone, however I do encourage you to try it if you really wish to, theres no large download to deal with, in fact I assume that only those with the slowest of internet connections can download the game within 30 seconds, the game downloaded in less than ten for myself. In fact by the time I had clicked on my steam library to confirm it was downloading it was already finished. You don't have much to lose aside from an hour or two of time becoming disappointed.

reviewText:
Gameplay in City of Steam is very reminiscent of most action RPGs on the market today. In fact, quite a favorable comparison could be made to Diablo 2 or Torchlight 2 from the standpoint that players work to level up skills to make them more powerful. On first glance, City of Steam's combat system is terrific and it certainly isn't bad by any stretch of the imagination. What is boils down to is that it is uninspiring in ways that the aforementioned games are not. As players level, they are granted skill power-ups in one of three disciplines. Points are allotted according to a player's wishes and combat skills are granted. In the end, it's not that the combat system is poor, it's just so much more button mashing of 1-2-3, rinse repeat.

Players are faced with pretty standard fare and work from a belt of abilities learned over time that increase in damage and effectiveness. I played as a Warder and my character had the typical arcing swings of both a great sword and two one-handed swords. It's pretty cool that players can choose a second weapon set for different skills and ways to fight monsters. Weapons can be changed out on the fly and it's worth having that ranged weapon handy to aggro only the monsters you want to rush out.

Questing is pretty standard fare as well. Head to a quest hub, grab 3-4 quests, head to the instances needed for completion, turn them in and done. Again, it's not unusual, just uninspiring and not as well done as most. The quest givers are not voiced which, depending on your particular style, is either a good or bad thing.

Players can utilize an isometric over the shoulder camera or toggle a free ranging camera on the fly. This is a marvelous touch on behalf of Mechanist, something that most players will like very much. In addition, questing can be directed if a player gets lost simply by clicking on the directional arrow that will automatically take characters to the desired location.
Still in the end, combat gets repetitive very fast. Between the same look and feel of all the instances and mashing the same combination of buttons over and over, it's a rather tiresome affair.

I don't really mind this game, I've played  a couple hours and it's free. There are pay options but I haven't needed them yet.
The only bugbear I have is that at one point I had to by a potion from this machine to progress through the game, I didn't need real money to buy the potion but the instructions didn't state buy a potion from here to proceed so I almost got stuck.

Then there was trying to find lumber in one of the areas as part of a quest it was relatively hard to find.

I played this game in advanced mode where I could 360 the camera and use abilities and such, and I chose the fighter route because I wanted to tank it out.

I beat the bosses and such and got some good gear, it seems the bosses only sometimes drop gear sometimes they drop nothing and it's not clear that they will ever drop anything unless you redo the dungeon, beacause there is a limit to how much gold exp and a boss counter you can get per dungeon run through. Also bosses just keep respawning pretty quick if you hang around be prepared to refight the boss or run for the exit which is usually not far from the boss.

But I did get good gear and I picked skills that helped me solo dungeons because I don't always have friends to bail me out.
As far as what you need to put in to the game to play well thats the good point just a 50 mg download and small updates and your in.

As someone who deletes games off his computer because of file size especially mmos I don't like, I'm happy to keep this one going as it's not that big a deal leaving it on.

I can see why people don't like it but hell it gave me a motorbike in the first hour of the game and then upgraded it in the second and I don't care if the game auto drives me places if I click the quest button if I want to drive around I can and if I'm lost blammo a button that takes me where I need to go, pretty smick.

I give it a 8/10

P.S. on my comp it comes up with an error saying to close the program, I just minimzed it because the game runs fine then made sure I had read the error message and set my taskbar to auto hide so I could see the whole screen and everything was hunckydory.

I am not normally one for bashing a game, but the only thing I have played lately to being this bad was Alganon... This game is still better, but still...

Questing is pretty much pointless, all you have to do is click on the quest in your side list and your character will automatically walk you there.
You can't jump over anything... I have never seen a game that allows jumping where jumping is absolutely 100% pointless.
Very few customization options was also a big downer.

I think if more work had been put into this game before it was released, it would have been an absolutely AMAZING game to play.

As it is now though, it's just... Ugh.

reviewText:
This game follow the normal browser MMO guidelines.
-Login daily for rewards.
-Repetetive quests daily.
-Repetetive dungeons daily.
-Massive ammounts of delay.
-Bonuses for paying players.

Although alot can be accuired by just playing activly you cant help but feel inferior to the paying customers.
And there will always be a huge gap between the current top players and the others.
This is not a hardcore ♥♥♥♥♥♥me, it is more like a casual Facebook game. Just as addicting as one aswell.

The game has a great storyline for those interested in that.
It is set in a Steam Punk enviroment, so get ready to suit up your character! There are TONS of cosmetics to apply to your character.
The character creation is  at the very minimum when it comes to customization.

The downside is that the game itself is a lowfps game, you will be rockin' lowlowlow fps.
And the amsterdam" servers are either high as fawk or located in someones basement on dialup modem.
Im living in Sweden with a 100mbit fiber and usually ping 15 to Amsterdam
date:
but in this game im glad to get 150-250ping. Which result in constant delay and rollbacks.

So I leave this review with the following statement:
If you are a hardcore gamer looking for a new game to play hardcore
recommended:
move along.
You will just get annoyed by most of the above.
Casual players will most likely love the game once they get started and not notice the downsides i mentioned.
